articles.title: This state’s power prices are plummeting as it nears 100% renewables
articles.summary: South Australia is proving to the world that relying largely on wind and solar energy with battery back-up is incredibly cheap, with electricity prices tumbling by 30 per cent in a year and sometimes going negative
articles.content:
South Australia is proving to the world that relying largely on wind and solar energy with battery back-up is incredibly cheap, with electricity prices tumbling by 30 per cent in a year and sometimes going negative

South Australia has built huge solar farms like this one in in Port Augusta Brook Mitchell/Getty Images

As South Australia gets close to its goal of running purely on solar and wind energy, its electricity prices have dropped by a third in a year and are now the lowest in Australia. The state serves as a test case for the financial benefits that can be reaped from large-scale grid decarbonisation.

“South Australia is a world leader in terms of its renewable energy transition and with that comes risks, but now it is showcasing its successes,” says Tim Buckley, an independent energy analyst at Climate Energy Finance, an Australian think-tank based in Sydney. “South Australian consumers are starting to really benefit from sustained, lower power prices.”

South Australia generated 84 per cent of its electricity from solar and wind energy in the final quarter of 2025, the highest proportion of any major grid in the world. The state plans to reach 100 per cent by the end of next year.

This renewables push is driving down electricity prices. The independent Australian Energy Market Operator’s (AEMO) latest report shows that the average wholesale electricity price in South Australia fell by 30 per cent in the final quarter of 2025, compared with a year earlier. As a result, the state had the lowest price in Australia, along with Victoria, which has the second highest share of wind and solar energy in the nation.

This is a boon for the South Australian government because in the past, it has been criticised for driving up electricity prices with its rapid adoption of renewable energy. At times, the state has experienced large spikes in electricity prices when the wind hasn’t been blowing or the sun shining, because it has had to fall back on expensive gas energy. Owners of gas generators have charged high prices for this back-up energy to make up for its sporadic demand. Making matter worse, gas prices went up 500 per cent in Australia following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, says Buckley.

Free newsletter Sign up to The Earth Edition Unmissable news about our planet, delivered straight to your inbox each month. Sign up to newsletter

To address this price volatility, South Australia has built seven mega-batteries, each about the size of a football pitch. They are charged by adjacent solar and wind farms on windy, sunny days, then provide some back-up power on still, rainy days instead of gas generators. The latest two of these batteries went online in 2025 and contributed to the price lowering.

The success of South Australia’s batteries has inspired other Australian states to build their own. Last week, a report by consulting firm Rystad Energy noted that “utility-scale batteries are no longer a complementary technology in Australia’s power system – they are actively displacing gas generation across multiple states”. This has made Australia a “global proof point” for the effectiveness of the technology, it said.

Another contributor to falling power prices is a giant new wind farm in South Australia called Goyder South, which was switched on in October. The 412-megawatt wind farm is the biggest in the state and is expected to increase its wind generation by 20 per cent. “Basic economics says that if you build more supply, then prices go down,” says Buckley.

The AEMO report notes that wholesale electricity prices were actually negative in South Australia 48 per cent of the time in the last quarter. This meant the state was generating more electricity than it was using, so the price went negative to encourage electricity producers to stop producing, says Buckley.

In November, for example, South Australia set a new record when, at one point, it met 157 per cent of its electricity demand with renewable energy alone. On occasions like this, the surplus energy is soaked up by the state’s batteries, exported to neighbouring Victoria or curtailed, meaning wind and solar farms are temporarily disconnected from the grid.

At the same time, many South Australian homes have started using less grid electricity, or none at all, by powering themselves. Over half the houses in the state now have solar panels on their roofs, which provide power during the day. About 50,000 have also installed home batteries, which are charged by rooftop solar panels during the day and then provide power after the sun goes down. Since the federal Australian government began offering 30 per cent discounts on home batteries in July 2025, South Australia has installed the most home batteries per capita of any state or territory.

In December, the state finalised deals to build two more large wind farms so that it can meet its target of reaching 100 per cent net renewables next year. “I think the target is on track and these two new wind farms will be key enablers of that,” says Buckley.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant real-world achievement where South Australia is nearing 100% renewable energy, resulting in a substantial 30% drop in electricity prices and setting a global example for grid decarbonisation. This has broad societal benefits by lowering energy costs, reducing reliance on fossil fuels, and inspiring other regions to adopt similar technologies. The article provides detailed context on the renewable energy transition, battery storage solutions, and the impact on electricity prices, making it a substantial and inspiring environmental success story.

**What happened** – By late 2025, South Australia generated 84% of its electricity from wind and solar power, the highest share worldwide for a major power grid. articles.title: How Smart Lighting Can Cut Energy Waste in Commercial Buildings
articles.summary:
Smart lighting is a type of intelligent lighting system that uses sensors, automation, and connected...
The post How Smart Lighting Can Cut Energy Waste in Commercial Buildings appeared first on Earth911.
articles.content:
Smart lighting is a type of intelligent lighting system that uses sensors, automation, and connected LED technologies to reduce energy waste in commercial buildings. Lighting typically accounts for 15–20% of a commercial building’s electricity use, making it one of the most significant areas where organizations can lower consumption without sacrificing visibility or comfort.

Every building wastes energy because lights run when no one needs them. Smart lighting fixes that. It does so through occupancy detection, daylight responsiveness, scheduling logic, and efficient LED upgrades. This article explores how the technology works, why it matters, the types of systems available, and the key applications across industries. Readers will also learn about installation costs, common mistakes, implementation steps, and long-term operational advantages. The overall goal is to provide a complete guide to help organizations transform their buildings with efficient, automated lighting strategies.

What Is Smart Lighting and How Does It Reduce Energy Waste

Smart lighting continuously evaluates occupancy, daylight levels, time schedules, and usage patterns, then adjusts lighting output accordingly. Smart lighting reduces energy waste because its light output always matches actual need rather than running at a fixed brightness.

Adaptive controls prevent unnecessary consumption during off-hours, transitions between spaces, or periods of low activity.

The technology is especially compatible with LED lighting because LEDs deliver higher efficiency, longer lifespan, and more stable output than older fluorescent or halogen options. Companies often turn to specialists providing commercial LED lighting services when planning upgrades, since the transition requires careful sensor placement, fixture selection, and integration with automation platforms. Businesses that rely heavily on industrial LED lighting services also benefit from advanced controls that enhance safety and visibility while lowering energy use in extensive facilities.

The features of smart lighting include:

Sensor-driven automation

Daylight-based dimming logic

Networked communication between fixtures

Real-time energy monitoring

Remote configuration via dashboards

Integration with HVAC and building controls

Types of Smart Lighting Systems

Smart lighting systems fall into multiple categories that address specific commercial needs. These systems function as groups of technologies that use sensors and networked communication to reduce energy use. They include advanced platforms, such as networked lighting controls, as well as simpler solutions, such as occupancy-based lighting. Choosing the right type depends on building layout, operational hours, and sustainability goals.

Networked Lighting Control Systems: connect fixtures, sensors, and controllers into a single managed platform. It fits large buildings where facility managers need central oversight. Its working principles rely on real-time communication that adjusts brightness, schedules, and operational logic based on collected data. This category is common in corporate offices, educational facilities, and industrial plants.

Occupancy and Motion Sensor Lighting: detects movement or presence using infrared or ultrasonic sensing. It instantly fits the context of energy efficiency because lights turn on only when the space is occupied. When motion stops, lights dim or shut off, preventing the waste common in restrooms, hallways, and smaller offices.

Daylight Harvesting Systems: use photosensors to measure natural light levels and adjust artificial lighting accordingly. Their main applications appear in spaces with large window areas, such as open-plan offices, atriums, and retail environments. They reduce brightness when sunlight provides sufficient illumination.

Time-Based and Scheduling Lighting Systems: control lighting using predefined time intervals. They fit buildings with predictable operating hours. Their working principle is based on automated on-and-off cycles that eliminate lighting waste during nights, weekends, and low-use periods.

Wireless Smart Lighting Networks: use Bluetooth, Zigbee, or similar protocols to connect lighting components without physical cabling. These systems are ideal for retrofits, remodels, and multi-tenant environments where wiring is complicated or expensive.

The Advantages of Smart Lighting

Smart lighting delivers measurable savings on both energy use and climate impact. Studies from the U.S. Department of Energy show that automated LED systems typically reduce lighting electricity consumption by 60-80%, and for a midsize commercial building, this often results in tens of thousands of dollars in savings over a ten-year period. Because LEDs require far fewer replacements, maintenance costs drop as well.

The environmental benefits are even more compelling. Lighting accounts for nearly 5 percent of global CO2 emissions according to the Climate Group, and LEDs emit only a fraction of the carbon produced by incandescent and fluorescent technologies. Signify estimates that universal LED adoption could cut 800 million metric tons of CO2 annually. Smart lighting amplifies these reductions by ensuring lights operate only when needed, making it one of the fastest ways for a building to shrink its carbon footprint.

These improvements also support compliance with sustainability standards such as LEED, WELL and ENERGY STAR, which increasingly reward automated controls, verified energy savings and emissions reporting. Beyond efficiency, smart lighting enhances comfort and safety by delivering stable illumination and greater visibility in critical areas, while analytics give facility teams clearer insight into system performance.

These advantages make smart lighting a practical upgrade for organizations aiming to reduce operating costs, strengthen environmental performance and meet rising regulatory and reporting expectations.

How Do Smart Lighting Systems Compare to Traditional Lighting

Smart lighting systems outperform traditional lighting because they combine LED efficiency with automated controls. Studies summarized by the U.S. Department of Energy show that advanced lighting controls combined with LEDs typically reduce lighting energy use by 60-80% compared to conventional, manually operated systems. This reduction comes from occupancy sensing, daylight harvesting and scheduling that turn lights down or off when they are not needed.

Traditional fluorescent or incandescent lighting not only uses more electricity but also has a shorter lifespan. The U.S. Department of Energy reports typical LED lifetimes of 25,000 hours or more, compared with about 1,000 hours for incandescent and 8,000 to 15,000 hours for many fluorescents, which translates into fewer replacements and lower maintenance costs over time. Smart systems add another advantage by providing data on run hours and performance, allowing facility teams to monitor usage and troubleshoot problems in ways that older systems cannot.

Smart lighting delivers higher energy efficiency, automated control instead of manual switching, less frequent maintenance and full visibility into how the system is performing, while traditional lighting offers none of these capabilities.

How Much Does Smart Lighting Cost to Install in Commercial Buildings?

Smart lighting upgrades are typically priced per fixture. Industry assessments of luminaire-level lighting controls show incremental smart-controls costs of about $40 to $70 per fixture, which aligns with the $50-per-fixture range often seen in commercial projects.

Total project cost depends on the number of fixtures, the sensors selected and whether the system ties into a building management platform. Occupancy and daylight sensors generally range from around $40 to the low hundreds of dollars, depending on features and communication protocols. LED fixtures themselves vary widely by brightness and efficiency.

Because building layouts and wiring conditions differ, most organizations rely on a project-specific estimate rather than a universal dollars-per-square-foot number. What remains consistent is that smart lighting reduces energy and maintenance costs enough over time to offset much of the initial investment.

Putting Smart Lighting To Work

Advanced innovative lighting technologies offer the highest energy savings, especially when paired with efficient LED lighting installation and LED upgrades. The best performing systems combine occupancy detection, daylight optimization, and networked analytics.

Installing LED lighting requires coordinated planning and configuration. The main steps ensure that buildings achieve the highest possible efficiency, sustainability, and light quality.

Step 1: Conduct an Energy Audit

An energy audit is a process that measures current lighting conditions, wattage loads, and usage patterns. It is usable in all commercial buildings because it identifies opportunities to upgrade to LED energy-saving solutions. The audit informs fixture selection, sensor ranges, and projected ROI.

Step 2: Identify High Waste Zones

High-waste zones are areas where lights remain on even when occupancy is low. Restrooms, hallways, and break rooms often top the list. Identifying these zones provides a definitive answer about where smart controls will deliver immediate savings.

Step 3: Select the Right Smart Lighting System

Building type, operational hours, and integration needs determine whether occupancy-based systems, daylight harvesting, networked controls, or wireless platforms are the best fit. Commercial kitchens or restaurant environments often evaluate lighting alongside restaurant energy efficiency improvements and energy-saving strategies for restaurant equipment to ensure the entire workspace runs efficiently.

Step 4: Install Sensors and Controllers

Installing sensors and controllers requires a placement strategy based on line of sight, coverage zones, and behavior patterns. Motion and occupancy sensors must be positioned to detect entry points, natural movement paths, and areas where people spend the most time. This prevents false-offs and ensures the system responds only when needed.

Step 5: Set Up Scheduling and Automation Rules

Scheduling setup uses software logic to determine how lights behave throughout the day. It includes time-based controls, brightness thresholds, and adaptive responses to daylight. This improves sustainability and complements foodservice equipment sustainability efforts in mixed-use facilities.

Step 6: Monitor Energy Savings and Optimize Settings

Monitoring system performance provides a definitive answer about ROI. Software analytics show where energy savings occur and where adjustments can improve performance. This stage ensures long-term efficiency.

Common Mistakes Businesses Make When Upgrading to Smart Lighting

Companies upgrading to bright lighting often repeat predictable mistakes. Avoiding these helps achieve higher efficiency and better long-term performance.

The first mistake is poor sensor placement. If sensors face vents, reflective surfaces, or low-traffic areas, they either trigger unnecessarily or miss real movement. This leads to lights turning off at the wrong times or staying on when rooms are empty.

Another mistake is skipping post-installation optimization. The system needs fine-tuning in its first weeks so brightness levels, occupancy timeouts, and daylight responses match real conditions. Without this step, energy savings can drop quickly.

A third issue is limited staff training. If facility teams do not understand how to adjust schedules or troubleshoot sensors, minor errors compound, and the system performs below its potential.

Businesses also overlook routine maintenance. Even though LED displays last for years, sensors accumulate dust or drift out of calibration, and minor fixes keep the system reliable.

Some upgrades fail because companies mix incompatible components or fail to follow basic cybersecurity practices. Ensuring that devices communicate properly and that networked lighting is securely configured prevents long-term problems.

What Are the Best Smart Lighting Brands for Commercial Buildings

Smart lighting brands are manufacturers offering LED lighting solutions designed for durability, control, and efficiency. They include companies that specialize in LED lighting installation and technology-driven illumination systems. Premium brands provide advanced drivers, stronger controls, adjustable optics, and longevity features that support sustainability goals.

Top brands include:

Making Lighting Right For The Planet

Smart lighting offers one of the fastest and most effective ways to reduce energy waste in commercial buildings. The technology combines LED efficiency, automated controls, daylight responsiveness, and remote optimization to maximize performance.

Organizations that pair these upgrades with broader sustainability strategies, such as efficient commercial kitchen operations and energy-efficient kitchen equipment, can significantly reduce operating costs. Understanding the types of systems available, the costs involved, and the steps required for implementation, help building managers take the first steps to create healthier, more efficient, and more environmentally responsible spaces.

About the Author

This sponsored article was written by Nia Ross, a specialist in sustainable lighting strategy and commercial energy efficiency. Nia focuses on practical upgrades that help organizations reduce waste, lower operating costs, and improve environmental performance.
articles.reasoning: The article describes smart lighting technology that significantly reduces energy waste in commercial buildings, leading to large-scale environmental benefits such as substantial CO2 emission reductions and cost savings. It provides detailed context on how the technology works, its advantages, types of systems, and implementation steps, highlighting its broad positive impact on energy efficiency and sustainability for many organizations and the environment.

articles.title: Solutions to climate change challenges: 'We have all the tools', just not the will
articles.summary: Eve Irvine is very pleased to welcome Glaciologist Dr. Heïdi Sevestre and Explorer Matthieu Tordeur. They made the treacherous journey across Antarctica using wind power only: “it’s nature who decides in Antarctica.” They recorded “thousands of kilometres worth of data” that can help answer two urgent questions: whether warming is changing snowfall in ways that might partially offset coastal ice loss, and what the deep internal layers of Antarctic ice reveal about Earth’s past warm periods, including those “more than 130,000 years ago.”
articles.content:
Eve Irvine is very pleased to welcome Glaciologist Dr. Heïdi Sevestre and Explorer Matthieu Tordeur. They made the treacherous journey across Antarctica using wind power only: “it’s nature who decides in Antarctica.” They recorded “thousands of kilometres worth of data” that can help answer two urgent questions: whether warming is changing snowfall in ways that might partially offset coastal ice loss, and what the deep internal layers of Antarctic ice reveal about Earth’s past warm periods, including those “more than 130,000 years ago.”

articles.personality_title: Scientists complete wind-powered Antarctica journey to study climate change
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Antarctica is a vast, icy continent that holds important clues about Earth’s climate history. Understanding changes there can help scientists learn how our planet’s climate is shifting, especially with global warming.

**What happened** – Glaciologist Dr. Heïdi Sevestre and explorer Matthieu Tordeur crossed Antarctica using only wind power. Their journey was difficult and depended entirely on natural wind conditions. Along the way, they collected thousands of kilometers of data about Antarctic ice and snowfall.

articles.title: Best of Sustainability In Your Ear: GS1 Goes Wholechain To Track Beef Impacts
articles.summary:
Revisit an important conversation about understanding the source of your food. Consumers and grocers who...
The post Best of Sustainability In Your Ear: GS1 Goes Wholechain To Track Beef Impacts appeared first on Earth911.
articles.content: We explore how their collaboration will provide you with more information and how Wholechain’s platform might be used to calculate environmental impacts, such as deforestation and methane emissions, while helping companies comply with regulations that shape the world’s food supply, like the Food & Drug Administration’s Food Safety Modernization Act Rule 204, which requires business to maintain records of food production, processing, and distribution to enable rapid identification of contamination sources during a foodborne illness outbreak. We’ll also discuss how Wholechain’s blockchain technology could expand beyond cattle to other industries, creating more transparent, sustainable, and circular global supply chains. You can learn more about Wholechain at https://wholechain.com/ and about GS1’s traditional rectangular bar codes and next-generation 2D QR code, GS1 Digital Link at https://www.gs1us.org/
articles.reasoning: The article discusses a collaboration using blockchain technology to track beef production impacts, including deforestation and methane emissions, which promotes transparency and sustainability in food supply chains. This has broad environmental significance and potential for large-scale positive impact beyond a niche audience.
articles.personality_title: New technology tracks environmental impact of beef from farm to table
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Many people want to know where their food comes from and how it affects the environment. Beef production can cause problems like deforestation and methane gas, which harm the planet. New rules also require companies to keep detailed records of food production to keep food safe.

**What happened** – Two organizations, GS1 and Wholechain, have teamed up to use a special kind of technology called blockchain. This technology helps track every step of beef production, from the farm to the store. It records important information about the environmental impact, like how much forest was cut down or how much methane was released.

**Impact** – This partnership makes it easier for companies to follow safety rules and for shoppers to learn about the food they buy. The use of blockchain means the information is very secure and hard to change. It also helps the environment by encouraging better farming practices. This system could be used for other foods and products in the future, making many supply chains more open and responsible.

**What's next step** – The next step is to expand this tracking system to other industries beyond beef, so more products can be traced for safety and environmental impact. Companies will start using these tools more to meet safety laws and show customers where their food comes from.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A new blockchain system is helping track beef’s environmental impact and food safety, making supply chains clearer and greener.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une nouvelle technologie suit l’impact environnemental du bœuf de la ferme à l’assiette
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Beaucoup de gens veulent savoir d’où vient leur nourriture et comment elle affecte l’environnement. La production de bœuf peut causer des problèmes comme la déforestation et le méthane, qui nuisent à la planète. De nouvelles règles obligent aussi les entreprises à garder des dossiers détaillés pour assurer la sécurité alimentaire.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Deux organisations, GS1 et Wholechain, ont collaboré pour utiliser une technologie spéciale appelée blockchain. Cette technologie aide à suivre chaque étape de la production du bœuf, de la ferme au magasin. Elle enregistre des informations importantes sur l’impact environnemental, comme la quantité de forêt coupée ou de méthane libérée.

**Impact** – Ce partenariat facilite le respect des règles de sécurité par les entreprises et permet aux consommateurs de mieux connaître leur nourriture. La blockchain rend les informations très sûres et difficiles à modifier. Cela aide aussi l’environnement en encourageant de meilleures pratiques agricoles. Ce système pourrait être utilisé pour d’autres aliments et produits à l’avenir, rendant de nombreuses chaînes d’approvisionnement plus transparentes et responsables.

**Prochaine étape** – La prochaine étape est d’étendre ce système de suivi à d’autres industries au-delà du bœuf, pour tracer plus de produits en matière de sécurité et d’impact environnemental. Les entreprises commenceront à utiliser ces outils davantage pour respecter les lois et informer les clients.

**Une phrase clé** – Un nouveau système blockchain aide à suivre l’impact environnemental et la sécurité du bœuf, rendant les chaînes d’approvisionnement plus claires et plus écologiques.
articles.personality_title_es: Nueva tecnología rastrea el impacto ambiental de la carne de res desde la granja hasta la mesa
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Muchas personas quieren saber de dónde viene su comida y cómo afecta al medio ambiente. La producción de carne de res puede causar problemas como la deforestación y la emisión de metano, que dañan el planeta. También hay nuevas reglas que exigen a las empresas llevar registros detallados para mantener la seguridad alimentaria.

**Qué pasó** – Dos organizaciones, GS1 y Wholechain, se unieron para usar una tecnología especial llamada blockchain. Esta tecnología ayuda a seguir cada paso de la producción de carne de res, desde la granja hasta la tienda. Registra información importante sobre el impacto ambiental, como cuánta selva se taló o cuánto metano se liberó.

El uso de blockchain hace que la información sea muy segura y difícil de cambiar. También ayuda al medio ambiente al fomentar mejores prácticas agrícolas. Este sistema podría usarse en otros alimentos y productos en el futuro, haciendo que muchas cadenas de suministro sean más transparentes y responsables.

**Próximo paso** – El siguiente paso es expandir este sistema de rastreo a otras industrias más allá de la carne de res, para que más productos puedan ser monitoreados por seguridad e impacto ambiental.
